abstract:
In order to effectively study and monitor site conditions for future sampling in a body of water, such as a river or a stream, the method described involves taking photos at specific locations along the bankfull channel. The photos are taken at transects 1, 6, 11, 16, and 21. These transect points serve as important reference points to help characterize and visually assess site conditions.

The necessity of this method lies in its ability to provide valuable visual data that can be used for various purposes. For instance, when planning to relocate sample sites for future sampling, having a clear understanding of the existing site conditions is crucial. The photos taken from these specific transects help ensure consistency and accuracy in the selection of new sampling locations.

Moreover, this method offers several advantages over other data collection methods. It is non-invasive and does not require physical presence at the site, making it safer and more cost-effective than sending personnel to take measurements directly. Additionally, photos can be easily accessed, shared, and analyzed at a later time, allowing for more comprehensive and in-depth analysis of the site conditions.

In summary, taking photos from specific transect points along the bankfull channel is an effective and efficient method for collecting visual data that helps characterize and assess site conditions. This information is vital when planning to relocate sample sites for future sampling and offers several advantages over other data collection methods, such as being non-invasive and cost-effective.
